articles.headline: Lesson in Air Safety: 90 Seconds to Get Out
articles.snippet: Asiana flight attendants have won wide praise for quickly getting passengers off the plane that crashed in San Francisco on Saturday.
articles.abstract: Asiana flight attendants have won wide praise for quickly getting passengers off the plane that crashed in San Francisco on Saturday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Next time you’re on a plane at takeoff or landing, watch the flight attendant in the jump seat, seemingly lost in thought. Is she idly wondering where she parked her the car at the airport or what’s for dinner?

articles.headline: Reality Show Contestants Pay a Real-World Price
articles.snippet: Some “Big Brother” contestants who are using ethnic and sexist slurs have stirred up viewers and the CBS network.
articles.abstract: Some “Big Brother” contestants who are using ethnic and sexist slurs have stirred up viewers and the CBS network.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2000, when CBS first locked people in a fishbowl of a house and televised almost every second of their lives, there was a spate of bad press when a newspaper discovered that a participant had ties to the New Black Panther Party. The network quickly issued a statement that said it “will not tolerate nor permit any hate speech on the program,” called “Big Brother.”

articles.headline: Chief Leaves Barnes & Noble After Losses on E-Readers
articles.snippet: A new chief was named to lead the struggling Nook division, but the C.E.O.’s post will remain vacant for the time being.
articles.abstract: A new chief was named to lead the struggling Nook division, but the C.E.O.’s post will remain vacant for the time being.

articles.headline: American Tastes Branch Out, and Food Makers Follow
articles.snippet: Food companies are experimenting more and more with exotic flavors and ethnic staples to appeal to a rising number of Latino and Asian immigrants.
articles.abstract: Food companies are experimenting more and more with exotic flavors and ethnic staples to appeal to a rising number of Latino and Asian immigrants.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW BERN, N.C. — If chicken producers could breed a bird with three legs, they would.

articles.headline: U.S. Considers Faster Pullout in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: President Obama, frustrated in his dealings with President Karzai, is considering speeding up troop withdrawals from Afghanistan and even leaving no American troops after 2014.
articles.abstract: President Obama, frustrated in his dealings with President Karzai, is considering speeding up troop withdrawals from Afghanistan and even leaving no American troops after 2014.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Increasingly frustrated by his dealings with President Hamid Karzai, President Obama is giving serious consideration to speeding up the withdrawal of United States forces from Afghanistan and to a “zero option” that would leave no American troops there after next year, according to American and European officials.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: Trader’s Day in Court May Lack Some Details
articles.snippet: A case is seen within the S.E.C. and on Wall Street as a referendum on Goldman Sachs. But all of the details might not be presented.
articles.abstract: A case is seen within the S.E.C. and on Wall Street as a referendum on Goldman Sachs. But all of the details might not be presented.
articles.lead_paragraph: Next Monday, in a courtroom in downtown Manhattan, the Securities and Exchange Commission will begin what is likely to be its most prominent case stemming from the financial crisis: its case against Fabrice Tourre, a former Goldman Sachs trader who is accused of misleading clients by selling a mortgage securities investment that the government said was designed to fail.

articles.headline: Perelman Sues Old Friend Milken (Not to Worry. It Isn’t Personal.)
articles.snippet: One of the billionaire deal maker Ronald O. Perelman’s companies has sued Michael Milken and others on accusations of fraud.
articles.abstract: One of the billionaire deal maker Ronald O. Perelman’s companies has sued Michael Milken and others on accusations of fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: The billionaire deal maker Ronald O. Perelman loves to litigate, having tussled over the years with, among others, his former vice chairman, his onetime chief financial officer and the investment bank Morgan Stanley — not to mention his four former wives.

articles.headline: Regulators Examining Sales of Early Financial Data
articles.snippet: The New York attorney general is looking into early release of data after Thomson Reuters announced that it was suspending an early release of a consumer confidence survey to clients who paid extra.
articles.abstract: The New York attorney general is looking into early release of data after Thomson Reuters announced that it was suspending an early release of a consumer confidence survey to clients who paid extra.
articles.lead_paragraph: The financial industry is bracing for new scrutiny of services that give trading firms an advance look at market-moving data and news.

articles.headline: Financial Crisis Just a Symptom of Detroit’s Woes
articles.snippet: As officials negotiate in a last-ditch effort to spare the city the largest municipal bankruptcy in the nation’s history, residents say the city has worse problems than its $18 billion debt.
articles.abstract: As officials negotiate in a last-ditch effort to spare the city the largest municipal bankruptcy in the nation’s history, residents say the city has worse problems than its $18 billion debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — A question unimaginable in most major American cities is utterly commonplace in this one: If you suddenly found yourself gravely ill, injured or even shot, would you call 911?

articles.headline: Kroger Buys Rival Grocer Harris Teeter, Citing Potential for Growth
articles.snippet: The Kroger Company has agreed to acquire Harris Teeter Supermarkets for $2.4 billion as it seeks to expand in the Southeast and mid-Atlantic regions.
articles.abstract: The Kroger Company has agreed to acquire Harris Teeter Supermarkets for $2.4 billion as it seeks to expand in the Southeast and mid-Atlantic regions.
